Circular Memorandum As you are aware in most Administrations it is quite unusual Tor political Agents to receive papers direct from outside authorities or to address these authorities direct or repeat to them cogiies of communications adaressed to the Head of the Administration, owing however to the somewhat peculiar circumstances which exist in the Persian uuif i.e. delays in communication between my headquarters and the Agencies, some years ago I agreed to political Agents being sent direct by outside authorities, e.g. the inaia office and the uovern- ment of India, copies of papers addressed to me. 2. In doing so, however, I made it clear that {a) no decision should be taken by the political Agent, or (b) no approach be made to the local Ruler by him without prior reference to me; and (c) that no opinion should be expressed by the political Agent to outside authorities on papers received by him, also without prior reference to me. These instructions are obviously essential since the final responsibility for all political matters in the Persian (iulf rests on the Political Resident. 5. The system generally has worked well for several years, despite the disadvantage that every now and then a political Agent inadvertently overlooks my instructions. The only alternative would be for Political Agents not to receive any papers /-- 2 - |w papers direct, which would result in much delay and additional labour. 4. With regard to 2(c) above. What I had in mind was that in order to save time Political Agents could repeat to the India Ol'fice or other outside authority the result of action taken, without giving an expression of their opinion, which would be cnveyed separately to the Political Resident only. In view, however, of the difficulty of separating facts and opinion in such cases, I am of opinion it is best that Politi cal Agents should not, unless specifically instructed by me, repeat to outside authorities their reports to the political Resident. 1 5. The restrictions referred to in paragraph 2 aoove natural -ly apply with equal if not greater force to suggestions or expressions of opinion initiated by Political Agents, which should in no case be addressed or repeated to outside authori ties since the Political Resident may or may not agree with the views expressed by the Political Agent. ■ L he correct procedure in such cases is for the Political Agent to address the Poli tical Resident only. 6. I trust that Political Agents wall adhere strictly to the instructions contained in this Circular. Sd/- T.C. Fowle. Dear Prior, There has recently come to notice a tendency on the part of certain officers of the Political Service to address to officers of the Headquarters Secretariat Staff, or to Heads of Local Administrations, communica tions marked ^Private and Personal ft in which they give expression to views, preferences, and even complaints, about postings orders by vhich they are, or are likely to be, affected. 9 )# This practice is open to objection on more than one ground, first and foremost it is obviously essen tial that at a time like the present when war conditions are putting an unprecedented strain on the man power ox the Department, to an extent which is perhaps not generally realised, the high standard of public service and sense of duty expected of Political Officers should be maintained more scrupulously than ever before. 3. Secondly, though those responsible for making the postirg are well aware that a similar strain is being imposed upon individual officers by increasing work, private anxieties and shortage cf leave, it must be clearly recognised that the predominant objective can only be the employment of every officer in such a manner as to secure the greatest public benefit. In such circumstances private inconveniences may often have to be ruthlessly disregarded, and it is only when the circumstances that an officer wishes to bring to notice are such as to be relevant to his efficiency in the appointment to which it is proposed to post him that they can be seriously considered.4. Thirdly, it is clearly undesirable that informa tion of this nature should reach the Secretariat in the form of 'Private and Personal' letters. Hot only is such correspondence likely to give rise to the impres sion that private friendships can be exploited for official ends hut, strictly speaking, information privately given ought not to he disclosed or taken into consideration by those isha have to determine questions of posting, even though it may be clear that it ms the intention or the hope of the waiters of such letters that this would be done. 5. For these reasons it has been found necessary to issue this order that no letters or representations of the nature referred to above shall be addressed to Headquarters by officers belcw the rank of Second Glass Resident otherwise than through the Head of the Local Administration under which they are serving. Heads of Administrations are requested to discourage such refer ences as far as possible and are accorded the discretion to withhold them, the criterion being to forward only such information or requests which they judge as being desirable to be brought to official notice, or to the personal notice of the Political Adviser ar Foreign Secretary, in the interests of the public service. Further any such representations will be regarded as demi-official and will be taken on record and, if necessary, taken into account on the confidential file of the officer concerned, 6. I am to request that you will kindly inform all officers of the Indian Political Service serving under you in the above terms. In so doing you will perhaps make it clear that the tendencies to which exception is being taken have been observed hitherto only among a small proportion of the officers of the cadre. It is because they are becoming more marked that it has been-3- ■been considered necessary to draw attention to them In these general and comprehensive ordei s* Yours sincerely, Sd.O.K.Oaroe. titleInfo.title: 'File No. 1/3 CIRCULARS & OFFICE ORDERS received from RESIDENCY.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. Circled serial numbers (red for received correspondence; blue/black for issued correspondence) refer to entries in the notes at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1and terminates at the back cover with 72; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-66; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file comprises circulars and notifications issued by the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, primarily to the political agents at Bahrain, Muscat and Kuwait. The circulars include instructions on how different types of correspondence should be addressed so that they reach their appropriate destination or are treated correctly on receipt; the number of duplicate copies of differing types of correspondence that should be sent to the Residency for forwarding on to other agencies; that Political Agents should send all correspondence directly to the Political Resident and should not communicate themselves with outside agencies; notifications of new telegraph codes for organisations; and notifications of changes of individuals job titles, and the renaming of departments and offices.Other matters of note within the file include:instructions on how intelligence summaries should be structured, including to whom they should be sent; correspondence regarding the magistrate responsibilities of the Indian Assistant and how this is supervised;the re-opening of the British Consulate at Bandar AbbasRalph Ingham Hallows, Assistant Political Agent at Bahrain, who has been trained in civil law and has been learning Arabic; the file notes that Hallows has not been undertaking any judicial work in Bahrain, has not continued his language studies, and has not suggested arrangements to ensure that both skills are encouraged during his appointment.A message from the Prime Minister (Winston Churchill) in 1942 regarding the example he expects civil servants to set during wartime.A series of file notes which were maintained as a record of the correspondence in the volume can be found at folios 68-71.
